saint-maria-faustina-kowalska.name: Saint Maria Faustina Kowalska
saint-maria-faustina-kowalska.history:
Saint Maria Faustina Kowalska (born Helena Kowalska, 25 August 1905 – 5 October 1938) was a Polish Roman Catholic nun and mystic. She is known as a leading apostle of the Divine Mercy. Throughout her life, Faustina reported visions and visitations from Jesus and Mary. These visions led to the institution of the Divine Mercy devotion, including the Divine Mercy image and chaplet.

She was canonized by Pope John Paul II on April 30, 2000, becoming the first saint of the new millennium. Her feast day is October 5.

saint-ignatius-of-laconi.name: Saint Ignatius of Laconi
saint-ignatius-of-laconi.history:
Saint Ignatius of Laconi (born Vincenzo Peis, 10 December 1701 – 11 May 1781) was an Italian Roman Catholic professed lay brother of the Order of Friars Minor Capuchin. He was known for his profound humility, unwavering charity, and tireless service to the poor and sick in Sardinia. Despite suffering from severe ailments, he dedicated his life to begging for alms to support his community and distribute to those in need, always showing immense compassion.

He was canonized by Pope John Paul II on May 20, 2000. His feast day is May 11.

saint-anna-maria-taigi.name: Saint Anna Maria Taigi
saint-anna-maria-taigi.history:
Saint Anna Maria Taigi (born Anna Maria Giannetti, 29 May 1769 – 6 June 1837) was an Italian Roman Catholic mystic and stigmatist. A wife and mother of seven children, she lived a humble life dedicated to God and her family amidst ordinary circumstances. She was known for her extraordinary visions and prophetic gifts, often advising popes, cardinals, and heads of state on matters of Church and civil affairs.

She was canonized by Pope John Paul II on May 20, 2000. Her feast day is June 9.

saint-josephine-bakhita.name: Saint Josephine Bakhita
saint-josephine-bakhita.history:
Saint Josephine Margaret Bakhita (c. 1869 – 8 February 1947), also known as Mother Moretta ('our Black Mother'), was a Canossian religious sister who lived in Italy. She was born in Darfur, Sudan, and was kidnapped and sold into slavery at the age of seven. Despite enduring immense suffering and hardship, she maintained her faith, eventually found freedom, and dedicated her life to Christ by joining the Catholic Church. Her extraordinary journey from slavery to sanctity made her a powerful witness to human dignity and freedom.

She was canonized by Pope John Paul II on May 20, 2000. Her feast day is February 8.

saint-katherine-drexel.name: Saint Katharine Drexel
saint-katherine-drexel.history:
Saint Katharine Mary Drexel (26 November 1858 – 3 March 1955) was an American heiress, philanthropist, religious sister, and educator. Born into a wealthy Philadelphia family, she chose to dedicate her life and fortune to serving Native Americans and African Americans, establishing schools and missions. She founded the Sisters of the Blessed Sacrament, an order dedicated to this work.

She was canonized by Pope John Paul II on May 20, 2000. Her feast day is March 3.

saint-ignatius-maloyan.name: Saint Ignatius Maloyan
saint-ignatius-maloyan.history:
Saint Ignatius Maloyan (born Choukrallah Maloyan, 1869 – 1915) was an Armenian Catholic Archbishop of Mardin and a martyr. During the Armenian Genocide, he refused to renounce his Christian faith despite immense pressure and torture by Ottoman authorities. He was martyred by hanging, demonstrating heroic fidelity to Christ.

He was canonized by Pope John Paul II on October 21, 2000. His feast day is June 11.

saint-augustine-zhao-rong-and-119-compan.name: Saint Augustine Zhao Rong and 119 Companions (Martyrs of China)
saint-augustine-zhao-rong-and-119-compan.history:
Saint Augustine Zhao Rong and his 119 companions are a group of martyrs who died for their Christian faith in China between the 17th and 20th centuries. The group includes Chinese Catholics of all ages and walks of life, as well as foreign missionaries who brought the faith to China. They suffered persecution and death under various emperors and regimes due to their refusal to renounce Christianity.

They were canonized together by Pope John Paul II on October 1, 2000. Their feast day is July 9.

saint-cristobal-magallanes-jara-and-24-c.name: Saint Cristóbal Magallanes Jara and 24 Companions (Martyrs of Mexico)
saint-cristobal-magallanes-jara-and-24-c.history:
Saint Cristóbal Magallanes Jara and his 24 companions are a group of priests and laypersons who were martyred during the Cristero War in Mexico (1926-1929). They were executed for their defense of religious freedom and their refusal to comply with government restrictions on the Catholic Church. Their deaths became a symbol of resistance against anti-clerical persecution.

They were canonized by Pope John Paul II on May 21, 2000. Their feast day is May 21.

saint-maria-de-jesus-sacramentado-venega.name: Saint María de Jesús Sacramentado Venegas de la Torre
saint-maria-de-jesus-sacramentado-venega.history:
Saint María de Jesús Sacramentado Venegas de la Torre (born María Natividad Venegas de la Torre, 8 September 1868 – 30 July 1959) was a Mexican Roman Catholic religious sister. She was the foundress of the Daughters of the Sacred Heart of Jesus, dedicated to caring for the sick and elderly in hospitals. Despite facing challenges, she tirelessly worked to establish and run hospitals, providing compassionate care to those in need.

She was canonized by Pope John Paul II on May 21, 2000, becoming the first canonized female saint from Mexico. Her feast day is July 30.

saint-jose-maria-de-yermo-y-parres.name: Saint José María de Yermo y Parres
saint-jose-maria-de-yermo-y-parres.history:
Saint José María de Yermo y Parres (10 November 1851 – 20 September 1904) was a Mexican Roman Catholic priest and the founder of the Servants of the Sacred Heart of Jesus and of the Poor. He dedicated his life to serving the most marginalized, establishing hospitals, orphanages, and schools for the poor and abandoned. He worked tirelessly to uplift the dignity of the suffering and needy.

He was canonized by Pope John Paul II on May 21, 2000. His feast day is September 20.
